Posts.Content: this is the pathologists way of grading the tumor.  There are 3 areas that are looked at and then a final grade of low, intermediate or high.  So it seems like you should have one more number.  You dont mention tumor size or LN involvement, but it seems more treatment will be needed.
Posts.Title: negative hormone receptors

Posts.Content: tumor markers are substances released by the tumor which can then be used to monitor treatment or diagnnose.  In breast cancer, markers are used to monitor treatment.  This does depend upon the clinician as some do not use them at all.  The most common markers for BC include CA 15-3, CA 27.29 and CEA.
Posts.Title: Have Lots of questions

Posts.Content: this is the pathologists way of grading the tumor.  There are 3 areas that are looked at and then a final grade of low, intermediate or high.  So it seems like you should have one more number.  You dont mention tumor size or LN involvement, but it seems more treatment will be needed.
Posts.Title: negative hormone receptors

Posts.Content: Estrone is a naturally occuring estrogen in the body. There is no good resone for a pre menopausal woman to take it. It doesnt make MM frow but it could cause breast cancer to grow and it has no effect on the immune system.
Posts.Title: i Have mm . It's All Over my Breasts. Stage 4. I'm 31 Yrs Old.

Posts.Content: Doxil is doxorubicin in a different form. Hand/foot syndrom can occur but is usually not severe and cardiac toxicity can occur if the lifetime dose exceeds 550mg/m2. Dont stop playing golf !
Posts.Title: Doxil

Posts.Content: where is the lump?  For the breast, there are nodes in the center of the chest, under the arm, above the collarbone and under the breast.  If it is a LN then why is it swollen?  Any signs of infection in the breast?  Most swollen LN are not cancer, especially at 32.
Posts.Title: lymph node

Posts.Content: In the high-grade pattern, the DCIS cells tend to grow more quickly. Women with high-grade DCIS have a higher risk of invasive cancer, either when the DCIS is diagnosed or at some point in the future. They also have an increased risk of the cancer coming back earlier.  High-grade DCIS is sometimes described as comedo which refers to areas of dead (necrotic) cancer cells, which build up inside the tumor. When cancer cells grow quickly, some cells don't get enough nourishment. These starved cells can die off, leaving areas of necrosis.  Generally the treatment options include surgery, RT and hormones and yes, more agressive treatment is needed for high grade tumors.  Discuss these options with your doc.
Posts.Title: outlook

Posts.Content: the highest stage of BC is 4.  This requires metastatic disease.  Has she has a biopsy?  See if you can clarify her stage and tumor grade from the biopsy.  This will clarify things.  I would check the Lock of Love web site or your local ACS concerning the hair. God bless.
Posts.Title: Mother with breast cancer

Posts.Content: you could be referring to the pathology report.  The pathologist looks at 3 areas and scores them.  Since the max in each area is 3, the max total is 9.  This would be an agressive tumor.  A clinical stage would be helpful to know as well.
Posts.Title: Mother with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Im not sure I understand your question.  HER2 (human epidermal growth factor receptor 2) is a protein found on the surface of cells that, when functioning normally, has been found to be a key component in regulating cell growth. However, when the HER2 protein is altered, extra HER2 protein receptors may be produced. This over-expression of HER2 causes increased cell growth and reproduction, often resulting in more aggressive breast cancer cells.  Herceptin blocks these receptors, limiting cell growth.  If Herceptin is stopped then the receptors are not blocked and abnormal cell growth resumes.
Posts.Title: Herceptin~when you stop it, your body goes back to making the protein?

Posts.Content: Hard to say what tumor markers they were using, but a drop after chemo is good. Stage 4 is not good, as you probably know. Survival would usually be 18-24 months, however many patients can achieve remission. Treatment at this stage should include hormone therapy and/or chemotherapy including trastuzumab, depending on her HER2 status. Radiation therapy may be used and at this stage, clinical trials should be investigated. This link ranks the top cancer hospitals, but you can find many such rankings so its just a guide. http://www.aarpmagazine.org/health/Articles/a2003-01-17-cancerhospitals.html
Posts.Title: Looking For The Best Doctor For Stage 4 Met to Liver, Tumor Markers??....

Posts.Content: many women who have a  preventive procedure to remove the unaffected breast do so out of fear.  It it most likely only beneficial in patients with high risk features in the breast that did have cancer.  These high risk factors include atypical hyperplasias, elevated GAIL score, invasive histology and multiple tumors in the original breast cancer.  Discuss your risk with your doc and make your decision on facts not fear.
Posts.Title: need help with decision

Posts.Content: Ca 125 is a substance produced in the fallopian tubes, uterus, cervix and in the pleura (lining of the chest). The Ca 125 test measures a protein that may be released when cells are inflamed or damaged. Levels under 35 are normal. Ovarian cancer cells may produce an excess of Ca 125 as may some other cancers however an elevated ca 125 is not necessarily indicative of cancer. Also in early stages of cancer the Ca 125 may not be elevated. So, this test is used in combination with other tests to aid in diagnosis, monitor treatment and prognosis for ovarian cancer. Other markers are used for different cancers but the CA 125 would not normally be used for breast or lung cancer, which you had.
Posts.Title: Looking For The Best Doctor For Stage 4 Met to Liver, Tumor Markers??....

Posts.Content: that could be true, but since that risk is low, even doubling it would still be low.  There are many variables, but if the average woman has a 1% risk of BC in the next 5 years then your risk is only 2 %.  That means a 98% chance you wont get BC.  A better question is what risk you have based on your tumors characteristics.
Posts.Title: need help with decision

Posts.Content: On 4/9/2007 Me&myself wrote: help! I'm only 16, and I have a clear pus coming from the pores around my nipple. It's clear, and there is NO odor at all. Sometimes it comes on it's own, and other times...not. Well, it seems almost like a pimple, but it doesn't have the look or feel of one. It doesn't have the white or top part of a pimple, but it does become red. My nipples also itch. I don't want to talk to my mother or anyone, because it is too embarrassing for me. Please help!!It sounds like you are describing Montgomery glands or areolar skin glands. Their function is partially unknown, but scientists suppose they are there to lubricate the nipple/areola area.  These Montgomery glands can be about unnoticeable, or stand out as bumps on the areola. They often become more prominent during pregnancy.   It is possible they could become infected but it is not a sign of cancer.  Despite your embarresment, tell your mom and get it checked out.
Posts.Title: help! i'm 16 with clear pus coming from the pores around my nipple

Posts.Content: Don't worry so much. Women your age do not generally get breast cancer. Pain and tenderness is normal. Relax and worry about other things most 16 year olds worry about, like what shoes to wear, what time to meet at the mall and of course, boys.
Posts.Title: Help

Posts.Content: with high grade, one option is to have lumpectomy (at least) with a sentinal node biopsy (SNB) and post op radiation (RT) to prevent recurrence.  Talk with your physician about your options.
Posts.Title: estrogen receptor positive breast cancer..

Posts.Content: have you had surgery?  SNB?  Since its high grade you could have RT in addition to the tamoxifen.  Have you discussed options with your doc?
Posts.Title: estrogen receptor positive breast cancer..

Posts.Content: Breast cancer (like most other cancers) can be "cured" if caught early and completely removed by surgery.  Unfortunately, this rarely happens.  Cancer is often NOT caught early (no symptoms or symptoms ignored) or surgery is not possible or does not remove all the cancer and it returns. Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: not quite knowledgeable... but I need some help

Posts.Content: For most women with stage I or II breast cancer, lumpectomy and radiation therapy is as effective as mastectomy. Survival rates of women treated with these 2 approaches are the same. However, breast conservation therapy is not an option for all women with breast cancer.  This approach would be questionable with large tumors, younger patients or if you are premenopausal and have known BRCA mutations.  So it would seem like an appropriate option for you if your BRCA was negative.
Posts.Title: sentinal lymph biop. w/lumpectomy

Posts.Content: she falls in the cracks a little.  Node neg is good but its a failry large tumor and its high grade.  One recommendation is to get a PTPCR assay like Oncotype DX to help determine her recurrence risk.  Based on that score you can then determine what treatment is most appropriate.  Ask her doc about this. All the best.
Posts.Title: treatment

Posts.Content: with a 22 you have a 14% chance of recurrance at 10 years.  Hormone therapy and radiation reduce that to 6-7% and chemo another 1-2 %.  Is the chemo worth it?  Its up to you.  Some patients want to do everything possible.  Its hard to seperate the Taxol because they were all studied together.  (AC then T).  You already did the hard part (AC).  Taxol should not be too bad.  I wouldnt worry about the tumor size confusion.  Anything > 1 cm should probably be treated.  DIscuss all this with your onc until you are satisfied.
Posts.Title: Onconotype DX Score 22 4 cycles AC now taxol??

Posts.Content: IBC can be hard to diagnose without a biopsy.  Docs frequenty mistake it for spider bites, mastitis, etc.  What kind of doc are you going to?  OB/GYN probably have more experience than a GP, but its rare so even they may not see much of it.  Here is a good web site to look at. http://www.ibcresearch.org/
Posts.Title: questions about inflammatory breast cancer

Posts.Content: with a 3 cm tumor you need chemo even though your Oncotype score is in the gray area.  Sounds like you completed the AC.  Taxol will add some advantage but its hard to quantify.  It should be easier to tolerate than the AC.
Posts.Title: Onconotype DX Score 22 4 cycles AC now taxol??

Posts.Content: its never great news when cancer doesnt respond to standard chemotherapy, and she has metastatic disease which isnt great news either. However she does have a positive outlook and thats important. I say support her as best you can and dont say much to your family, right now. She is dealing this in her own way, as best she can.
Posts.Title: Supporting my Sister

Posts.Content: It sounds like you are doing the right thing. Why does radiation scare you? Arimidex may cause some hot flashes, but thats about it. There is good data that this plan will prevent your cancer from recurring. Hang in there.
Posts.Title: Arimidex and Radiation

Posts.Content: Oncology is always mired in risk/reward decisions.  What is the benefit of a treatment and how much will I pay for that benefit?  4% isnt much unless youre in that 4%.  Recurrent breast cancer is nasty.  Be sure you know what the risk is instead of making a decision based on fear.  What chemo would you get?  What are the side effects of that treatment (some have very little) ?  How would the treatment impact your life?  Talk to patients who have had the same treatment to see how they did.  Then you can make a decision based on facts....not fear.  The steroids you mentioned would be low dose given to prevent reactions to certain chemo drugs.  They shouldnt have an impact on your health... if you even get them.
Posts.Title: Difficult Personal Decision

Posts.Content: Usually the indication for prophylactic mastectomy is BRCA +. This is because 80% of these patients develop breast cancer. I would probably not take such a severe stance in your case although I am not sure what the BRCA varient means. Annual exams, frequent BSE's and annual mamograms should keep an eye on things pretty closly. Still this is a personal decision and you must do what you and your family think is best.
Posts.Title: Prophylatic Bilateral Mastectomy

Posts.Content: does she have any health insurance?  You could ask the hospital Social workers for help.  Usually the oncology floors have dedicated staff for these issues.  Also she could check out www.pparx.org and www.needymeds.com which can help her deal with the drug companies patient assistance programs.
Posts.Title: fund raiser for friend with breast cancer, and ideas?

Posts.Content: On 5/11/2007 Marilli wrote: Does anyone have any information on Heparan Sulfate?  Is it FDA approved, is it a chemo, hormonal drug?  Any information would be appreciated.  Thank you.I am wondering how you came across this.  Technically, it is a polysaccharide  found in all animal tissues. it regulates a wide variety of biological activities, including developmental processes, angiogenisis, blood coagulation and tumour metastasis.  Heparin sodium has a medical use as an anticoagulant.  I am not aware of a medical use for heparan sulfate.
Posts.Title: Heparan Sulfate

Posts.Content: interesting.  As you can see this is still being used in animals.  It has a long way to go for human use.  Thanks for the update.
Posts.Title: Heparan Sulfate

Posts.Content: As you probably know, stage 4 IDC has a rather poor prognosis. You didnt mention her ER, PR status or the her2 status but stage 4 implies lymph node involement and distant mets. The medial survival is probably 18-24 months with a 5 year survival of about 5%. Still miracles do occur. Talk with her doctors about options, look into clinical trials and pray. God bless.
Posts.Title: Stage 4

Posts.Content: A papilloma is a benign (noncancerous), wart-like growth in a milk duct of the breast. It is usually found close to the nipple and may cause a clear, sticky, or bloody discharge from the nipple. It may also cause pain and a lump in the breast that can be felt or seen. It usually affects women aged 35-55 years. Having an intraductal papilloma does not increase the risk of developing breast cancer.
Posts.Title: Breast Disease

Posts.Content: I am not a her2 + patient , but I am an Oncology Pharmacist. It sounds like the numbness and vision problems are most likely due to Taxol and should resolve over time. Herceptin may cause some nausea, chills or cough and rarely some heart problems. Stick with it, its been a great drug for many patients.
Posts.Title: Herceptin

Posts.Content: Calcifications are tiny flecks of calcium in the soft tissue of the breast that can sometimes indicate the presence of an early breast cancer. Calcifications usually can't be felt, but they appear on a mammogram. Depending on how they're clustered and their shape, size, and number, your doctor may want to do further tests like a biopsy. No need to worry just yet.
Posts.Title: New To Board - Mammogram Birad 4

Posts.Content: Most lumps are nothing and breast cancer in someone so young is very unusual. Relax and get it checked as soon as you can.
Posts.Title: Someone Help!!!

Posts.Content: Yes, studies show that post op radiation does improve survival. She should talk with her radiation oncologists about her fears. They can aim the radiation exactly where they need to.
Posts.Title: Moms Cancer

Posts.Content: treatment depends upon stage.  In stage I, surgery +/1 RT is usual.  No hormones because of her ER/PR status.  If the tumor is smaller than 1 cm  adjuvant chemotherapy is not usually offered. Some doctors may suggest adjuvant chemotherapy if a cancer smaller than 1 cm has any unfavorable features (such as being high-grade, estrogen-receptor negative, or HER2-positive).  Adjuvant chemotherapy is usually recommended for larger tumors.  It may be possible to test to see if chemotherapy would be of value using the genetic tests Oncotype or Mammaprint.
Posts.Title: Mom Diagnosed Need Advice

Posts.Content: I agree that offering Tamoxifen in the absence of a diagnosis or even ER/PR status sounds a little strange.  As others have said, mamograms and MRI's are not good at detecting something that is not a discrete mass.  IE,  IBC.  For this, you need a biopsy.  A physicain with experience may be able to tell from a PE that a biopsy is not warrented and that this is not cancer.  Its hard to diagnose via the internet, but this is your body and if you feel something isnt right, keep pressing.  My experience is that the patient is frequently right.
Posts.Title: Hello..I have a few questions...

Posts.Content: since you are post menapausal either Tamoxifen or Arimidex could be used.  Arimidex has become the standard because it has shown to prevent the cancer from returning much better than tamoxifen.  Still if the side effects are that bad, I wouldnt put up with it either.  Another possibility is the other aromatase inhibitors Femara and Aromasin.  They may not have the same side effects.
Posts.Title: estrogen inhibitors

Posts.Content: Only about 30% of BC patients are HER2 + and would benefit from Herceptin. It is now being used in first line therapy for those patients and is showing great promise.
Posts.Title: Herceptin or Not

Posts.Content: http://cancerresearchjournal.com/2007/12/24/enzyme-determine
Posts.Title: Effectiveness of Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Stage 4 means she has distant mets which you already know have shown up in her lung and bones. The prognosis for stage 4 isnt great with a 5 year survival rate of 16%. Im sure her cancer can be "managed", but that doesnt mean she isnt dying from it.
Posts.Title: Stage 4 Into Spine

Posts.Content: The chance of invasive cancer or more DCIS depends on several things. Find out from your biopsy, what type of DCIS you had. Some are more aggressive than others. Find out about your margins (they should be 1-10 mm or clear). Find out how large the DCIS is that was removed. For some patients who have a large area of DCIS or several areas of DCIS, mastectomy is the best option. Depending upon the answers to these questions you may need radiation therapy, more surgery or tamoxifen. Discuss these options with your physician. God bless.
Posts.Title: Dcis

Posts.Content: that sounds right for stage 4, ER +. If she has disease progression on this, then chemo would be indicated.
Posts.Title: Stage iv - no Chemo

Posts.Content: Pathologists observe three features when determining a cancer’s grade: the frequency of cell mitosis (rate of cell division), tubule formation (percentage of cancer composed of tubular structures), and nuclear pleomorphism (change in cell size and uniformity). Each of these features is assigned a score ranging from 1 to 3 (1 indicating slower cell growth and 3 indicating faster cell growth). The scores of each of the cells’ features are then added together for a final sum that will range between 3 to 9. Since all your scores were 3 and you had necrosis, this tends to indicate an agressive tumor with a higher possibility of recurrance.  I dont think the 17 th is too late , but get started as soon as you can.  Most likely surgery, radiation and chemo will be needed.
Posts.Title: Invasive ductal adenocarcinoma

Posts.Content: Researchers have performed a study showing an gene that lowers levels of a key enzyme that may indicate whether Tamoxifen will effectively treat women with a common type of breast cancer.  It appears if you had the defect then you cant metabolize the drug properly and the side effects were greater.  However larger studies are needed to confirm this before women routinely get tested.
Posts.Title: Effectiveness of Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: you dont provide much info like stage, biopsy results, surgery, etc, but TAC has shown some good results in early stage BC.  Oral drugs in BC are limited to hormone therapy, after surgery.  Could you find a clinic/office that is closer and able to give your TAC?
Posts.Title: oral chemo

Posts.Content: The early results of studies show promise for women with advanced HER2-positive breast cancer that has stopped responding to Herceptin. The combination of Tykerb and Xeloda essentially delayed the cancer's growth nearly twice as long compared with Xeloda alone. So far, Tykerb hasn't improved overall survival. Longer follow-up time is necessary to know if Tykerb will improve overall survival. And unlike Herceptin, Tykerb doesn't seem to be associated with serious heart problems, at least in these early results. More studies are needed to confirm these results. Also, Tykerb can be taken in pill form and thus is easier than receiving medicine through an IV. Does this make it better? Not necessarily,just different.
Posts.Title: is Tykerb Better Than Herceptin?

Posts.Content: You mentioned you were stage 1 yet had LN involvement.  This would be stage II at a minimum.  From your path report it would be helpful to know ER/PR status, HER status, Ki 67 and tumor grade.  One option to ask your doc about is Oncotype Dx which is a gene profile which will help determine your chance of recurrance.  If low , then lumpectomy and adjuvant therapy is probably OK.  If high, then you may want to consider a mastectomy.  Keep in mind a mastectomy is an unlikely option down the road if this recurs as metastatic disease.
Posts.Title: feeling alone

Posts.Content: the problem with running Aredia in too fast would be kidney damage. You should get a serum creatinine level prior to your next dose. I dont think one dose at an increased rate would be that harmful, but make sure the creatinine level is done. I also think it is a medication error and your physician should have been notified.
Posts.Title: Pomidrinate / Aredia

Posts.Content: Happy New Year !  Try and stay positive until you know something different.  You may have already done some online research but here is a wedsite worth visiting. http://www.ibcsupport.org/
Posts.Title: Happy New Year? maybe not

Posts.Content: the problems with Zometa and ONJ involved more invasive procedure like dental surgery, not cleanings or fillings.  If you want the tooth pulled then I would say a month or so.  For you its been 3 months, so that seems fine.  The possibility of problems is low, 5 % or so.  I would also check with your Onc and dentist to see what they say.
Posts.Title: Breast cancer with mets to the bone

Posts.Content: its a good question and you can find different opinions even amoung docs.  I would think RT with Tamoxifen (if ER+) would be enough in stage 0.  In stage 1 chemo is an option.  I would ask the doc to explain the advantages of chemo vs no chemo and its impact on quanity and quality of life.
Posts.Title: to chemo or not to chemo? that is the question

Posts.Content: Tykerb in combination with Xeloda was recently approved for the treatment of patients with advanced or metastatic breast cancer whose tumors overexpress HER2 and who have received prior therapy including an anthracycline, a taxane, and trastuzumab. It is the first targeted, once-daily oral treatment option for this patient population.   Tykerb is to be given continuously until progression or unmanageable toxicity occurs.
Posts.Title: Tykerb

Posts.Content: was yours invasive or DCIS?  Generally its unusual for someone who has a bilateral for DCIS to be prescribed AI's/Tamoxifen.  Certainly there is a low risk of local or distant recurrence (about 1% - 2%)  but most oncologists feel that this risk level is sufficiently low that AI's/Tamoxifen arent necessary.  If you had invasive BC ( even with neg nodes) then its a different story.
Posts.Title: Chosing NOT to take aromisin inhibitor?

Posts.Content: Lots of things cause lymph nodes to swell. There is some concern when that is combined with bone pain and "not feeling well". The doc is checking for breast cancer that may have spread to lymph and bone. But that is why you are getting it checked out. Dont worry until there is somethig to worry about.
Posts.Title: Dr. Found Lump in Lymph Node Under Arm

Posts.Content: you cant predict side effects before you even start.  Every patient is different.  You may have no problems.  Even if you do, you should be able to work with your doc to minimize side effects while obtaining the desired benefit.  How much more will you have to give up?  How about your life if it returns because you were worried about some side effects that might occur.
Posts.Title: Chosing NOT to take aromisin inhibitor?

Posts.Content: BC outcome is largely determined by type, grade and stage.  Do you have any of this info yet?
Posts.Title: I Just Found Out I Have Breast Cancer!

Posts.Content: "pain" is normal at your age. Dont worry. Even most lumps are nothing. Learn how to do self exams and do them on a regular basis. Relax....you are fine.
Posts.Title: Hello

Posts.Content: A biopsy is the only way to get a definative diagnosis. Its quick and painless. Other non-invasive options include MRI, ultrasound and perhaps digital mamography. You may have had some of those already. I assume there has been no change in size of the lump which would be good. Still a biopsy is the only way to be sure and only you can decide. It sounds like a good idea.
Posts.Title: Should i Get a Biopsy?

Posts.Content: On 2/20/2007 Jean1 wrote: Hi my mom is 72 she has recently 11 days ago had a right mysectomy .She had invasive ductal carcinoma stage 3.She had a sentanal node biopsy all nodes negative.Just got tests back and this is what it says ductal carcinoma in situ grade 3 necrosis present comedo pattern margins now clear .six lymph nodes all negative for metastic carcinoma ..this i am confused on estrogen receptor..negative,positive internal control ...progesterone receptor negative positive internal control ..herceptest (DAKO)equivocal,40%,1+/weak to 2+moderate specimen sent for florescence in situ hybridization......Im confused does this mean additional things are needed like chemo,radiation and or hormone therapy.She is not sure if this is good or bad and we are  a little confuused ..I'm just tired from lack of sleep from taking care of her !! She does have an appt with an onchology in 2 weeks HELP!!! I need  it explained this has all happened so fast she has been very depressed and I am not understanding.She asked the dr today what her survival rate is ..??? any help would be such a blessing!! thank you tara The DCIS is a good sign.  It a localized cancer.  The negative margins and negative lymph nodes also say that.  The grade 3 indicates a cancer that is rapidly growing.  Its the highest grade and means a more likely chance of recurrance.  The necrosis also indicates this.   The cells are growing so fast the blood supply cant keep up and some of them die (necrose). Her estrogen and progesterone receptors are negative.  This isnt necessarily bad, it just means the hormonal therapy wont work.  The HER 2 receptor appears to be moderate to weak by DAKO with FISH pending.  This test indicates if the drug Herceptin will be of benefit.  Probably not, but the FISH test may say different.  So, I would say she has an agressive cancer that was caught early.  She will most likely need more treatment, perhaps just radiation, but you should discuss that with her doc.  DCIS, even when agressive has a pretty good prognosis.  Hope this helps a little.
Posts.Title: my moms test results?? help

Posts.Content: On 2/21/2007 Jean1 wrote: yes that helps alot .She has not been following her results and everything .I have done alot of research but some things are hard to understand.She asked me if her cancer could or has spread to other parts her body bacause it it a fast growing type of cancer (being that it was not in her lypph nodes.I asked about pet or ct scan for her body .she has had alot of coughing and the dr said her chest xray showed fine is there any blood or scan testing that can give her/us any more comfort that nothing has spread.So would radiation be beneficial.I am thinking they will put her on herception.but we are still waiting to find out also can you recommend any good support groups?she has been very depressed thank you so much and god blessIt certainly could spread, but you caught it pretty early.  DCIS is almost always cureable.  Its probably too early for scans to be of much benefit.  However, I would assume they are part of her routine followups.  I think radiation is an option as is HERCEPTIN if FISH is +.  I would press for an antidepressant like Celexa or Lexapro.  They can help alot.  Support groups can be helpful.  Do a search on the Web or check with your local American Cancer Society.
Posts.Title: my moms test results?? help

Posts.Content: it would appear to me that your mom has a 10% chance of dieing of cancer in the next 10 years , if you do nothing.  However she has a 20% chance of the cancer returning in the next 10 years , if you do nothing.  In other words, her cancer probably wont kill her in the next 10 years, but it may return.  Your objective is to reduce that chance that it could return, because if it returns, it will be hard to fight.  That decision is hers.  The chemo that you mentioned isnt too bad, but it will have some side effects.
Posts.Title: my moms test results?? help

Posts.Content: Outside of clinical trials, usual treatment for SLN-positive patients is an ALND. However, since axillary node metastases are limited to the SLN in more than half of SLN-positive individuals, there may be some patients for whom an ALND is not required.  You should discuss pros and cons with your surgeon.   In addition, you should get further treatment because of the + LN.  Dont give up.
Posts.Title: Lymph Dissection

Posts.Content: As you realize, the prognosis for recurrent breast cancer isnt that great, although you didnt describe the type or stage of the cancer. It sounds as if you care for her a great deal and considering that, it seems as if you should be with her during this difficult time. Perhaps you could take a leave from school. Remember this, you have the rest of your life for school, but you may not have that much time to spend with your mom. Years from now it will be very comforting to look back and realize you did everything you could for her.
Posts.Title: Help?

Posts.Content: inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) can have the following symptoms:  Rapid, unusual increase in breast size. Redness, rash, blotchiness on breast. Persistent itching of breast or nipple. Lump or thickening of breast tissue. Stabbing pain and/or soreness of breast.  this cancer is agressive, fast growing  and hard to treat.  If she has any doubts, tell her to get it checked ASAP.
Posts.Title: has anyone ever had this symptom

Posts.Content: IBC or Inflammatory Breast Cancer is not a single lump but causes breast changes in the nipple and surrounding areas. This can also cause your skin to look like an orange peel ( except for the color).  Other symptoms include rapid increase in breast size, redness, persistent itching, skin hot to the touch. IBC often initially resembles mastitis, and is sometimes misdiagnosed as an insect bite.  IBC is nothing to mess with.  Get it checked out.
Posts.Title: Is this ok?

Posts.Content: Treatment for BC depends upon histology and stage.  If caught early, no adjuvant treatment may be needed.  From there it just depends.  Perhaps just RT, perhaps chemo, perhaps hormones, etc.  I agree at 88 nothing heroic is necessary.  Let us know when you get more details.
Posts.Title: breast cancer in my 88 yr. old mother

Posts.Content: I wouldnt panic just yet.  Prognosis depends upon many factors including stage, size of tumor, grade, type, surgery options ,etc.  You didnt reveal any of that.  Great strides have been made in recent years in the treatment of BC.
Posts.Title: Lucky Me

Posts.Content: When this drug got FDA approval for BC in 2008 there was some controversy.  There was no survival increase and a relatively modest PFS advantage.  As is standard, the FDA granted approval but asked for confirmatory studies.  Those studies showed no PFS advantage so the indication will probably be removed.  This has happened before with other drugs so its really just normal business proceedings for the FDA rather than a "stunning rebuke."  Moss is a pro-alternative medicine guy who has a PhD in literature.
Posts.Title: AVASTIN: stunning reversal

Posts.Content: A malignant lump will have an irregular shape (not round) with a pebbly surface, somewhat like a golf ball. It will be very hard, like a slice of raw carrot. It may not be moveable during a BSE, but since tissue around it may move, it’s sometimes hard to know if the lump is moving, or if healthy tissue around it is moving. A clinical breast exam and a mammogram will help to clear up the diagnosis. A biopsy would provide the clearest information about the lump. But as you say, you need to get it checked, especially given your family history.
Posts.Title: Is a small nodule really that worrisome?

Posts.Content: This is still in Phase II trials but there was a report at ASCO last month that showed promise.  The study is comparing the combination to Tykerb alone.  The neat thing is that both these drugs are oral.  Lapatinib is currently available as Tykerb while pazopanib is still investigational.  Its being used in HER2 + patients only.
Posts.Title: Info on PAZOPANIB/LAPATINIB

Posts.Content: Breast cancer can grow fast and be hard to treat. How old is you mother? Do you know what stage she had or the HER status or hormone status? These tests would be needed to determine the next steps to take.
Posts.Title: Can a Tumor Grow That Fast?

Posts.Content: On Feb 22, 2011 6:37 PM passionfish wrote: I`m wondering if anyone out there has been dx with DCIS and made the decision not to have bilateral masectomy? I had breast reduction  and upon return for stitch removal was informed that I had DCIS in right breast and DCIS & LCIS in my left breast..They scooted me down to the surgeon who recommended immediate bilateral masectomy. I chose to go into Dana Farber for a second opinion..The team there disagreed with the pathologist dx and suggested that I do a "watch and wait" ...they did inform me that most women choose the surgery over the watching...needless to say that was a number of years ago and all is still well...I am wondering if anyone has chosen the same path and if so, how they are doing??  I have to admit that I`m a bit haunted over the decision and occasionally wonder what could be "cookin" inside my breasts.. Sorry for the lengthy post....Adonna I think your decision was a wise one.  The 10 year survival rate for DCIS is 98-99%.  You cant increase that by much.  Surgery may increase that to 100% but at what cost?  I think women choose surgery because they want the problem gone and because cosmetically its not a concern to them.  Thats OK, but their survival does not improve that much.
Posts.Title: DCIS & LCIS dx decided no bi lateral masectomy

Posts.Content: is the tumor in her right breast? Recurrant and resistant breast cancer does have a worrisome prognosis. The antiangiogenesis drug Avastin is involved in clinical trials for breast cancer, but Im not sure than any advantage has been shown so far. To view open clinical trials, go to the NCI or the NCCN sites and look under clinical trials.
Posts.Title: my Mom is 48, Mets to Bone, Need Advice

Posts.Content: Two studies have confirmed the benefit of taking adjuvant tamoxifen daily for 5 years. These studies compared 5 years of treatment with tamoxifen with 10 years of treatment. When taken for 5 years, the drug reduces the risk of recurrence of the original breast cancer and also reduces the risk of developing a second primary cancer in the other breast. Side effects can be similiar to menopause. Discuss side effects with your doc. They be be unpleasant, but they are MUCH less unpleasant than having your cancer return.
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: this study was stage 1 or 2 breast cancer only.  These patients already have pretty high survival rates, so its hard to improve them much.
Posts.Title: DCIS & LCIS dx decided no bi lateral masectomy

Posts.Content: Yes, this does happen with biphosphonates. Here is some more information. Fosamax ( generic name - Alendronate ) and Zometa are types of drugs known as bisphosphonates. Recently a link has been found between bisphosphonates and a serious bone disease called osteonecrosis of the jaw ( ONJ ). This important discovery clearly shows that Fosamax side effects may include osteonecrosis of the jaw. The discovery, published in the Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgeons, prompted both the US, Food and Drug Administration ( FDA ) and Novartis, the manufacturer of bisphosphonates used in cancer chemotherapy, to issue a warning to health care professionals on September 24, 2004. The warning letter contained information about bisphosphonates and the risks of osteonecrosis in the jaw. Bisphosphonates are commonly used in tablet form such as Fosamax ( Alendronate Sodium ) to prevent and treat osteoporosis in post-menopausal women. Stronger forms of bisphosphonates are commonly used in the management of advanced cancers that have metastasized to the bone, where the disease often causes bone pain and possibly even fractures. Several cancers can involve or metastasize to the bone, including lung cancer, breast cancer, prostate cancer, multiple myeloma, and others. When bisphosphonates are given in cancer chemotherapy, the drugs are given intravenously, and usually for longer periods of time.
Posts.Title: Jaw Bone Problems

Posts.Content: Keep in mind, I am NOT saying you have ONJ, I am just saying biphosphonates can cause it. Your doc should be able to diagnose this. The best treatment is to get off the biphosphonate.
Posts.Title: Jaw Bone Problems

Posts.Content: early breast cancer often has no signs.  Thats why mammogram screening is important.  In addition, breast self exams and an annual exam by your doc are also important.  Signs include any changes in your breast including lumps, swelling, discharge, hot feeling, skin changes, etc.
Posts.Title: What are the early signs of breast cancer?

Posts.Content: Over 80 % of the time breast lumps are NOT cancer. Signs that the lump is NOT cancer include: the lump is soft, it is easy to distinguish, it moves, there are several lumps, there is an identical lump in the other breast, the lump disappears after your cycle. I havent had the same issues but I can say the odds are in your favor that it is nothing.
Posts.Title: Unknown

Posts.Content: Most nipple discharge is not indicative of cancer. Other possibilities include cysts, infections and other things. ANy other symptoms like puckering of the skin or an inverted nipple or a warm feeling in the breast? You are wise to get it checked but dont panic just yet.
Posts.Title: Could This be Breast Cancer?

Posts.Content: its an option to consider with your physician.  Yours sounds like 2A, triple negative, neg nodes.  Are you getting radiation?  Given that yours is grade 3 ,chemo may be a good choice.
Posts.Title: Should chemo be given after MRM in 76 year old lady patient

Posts.Content: I think that sounds reasonable.  Your Oncotype is in the intermediate range which means its not low risk, but not high either.  That means using chemo is unclear.  You need tamoxifen because of the ER/PR.  Do you know a HER status?  The cytoxan/mtx shouldnt be too bad.  Tamoxifen will probably be worse.
Posts.Title: Cytoxan/Methotrexate anyone????

Posts.Content: I am not a patient so I speak from observation, not experience.  You will probably lose your hair.  If its a concern, you may ask about a cold cap.
Posts.Title: Cytoxan/Methotrexate anyone????

Posts.Content: Dont worry about tomorrow until it gets here. Most lumps and abnormal mammograms are not cancer. Chances are it is nothing.
Posts.Title: Unknown

Posts.Content: fatigue and depression are real problems in cancer.  Does she take the antidepressants?  Does she take any other meds that could contribute to the problem  (pain meds, nausea meds) ?  Could someone be with her so she is not alone all day (could you hire a sitter)?  In the final analysis, you cant will someone to fight this.  They must be an active participant.  She must believe she can beat this and engage in the process of doing so.  However, that is up to her, not you.
Posts.Title: i need help...

Posts.Content: is she post menopausal? If so, the practice guidelines would call for one of these drugs for 5 years after the tamoxifen. Osteoporosis and flashes are possible, but less than 40% of patients get them. I would be inclined to stick with the guidlines, but it is her choice.
Posts.Title: What to Use After Using Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: lumpectomy and radiation should be fine.  No spread if its really DCIS.  You could need tamoxifen depending on your ER/PR status.  Dont worry, it sounds like you caught it early.  Nearly 100% cure for DCIS.
Posts.Title: Need some support on what to do Re: DCIS

Posts.Content: keep in mind, these drugs do not lowers hormone levels, they block receptors.  Even in tumors that are ER-/PR+, tamoxifen is of benefit unless you are also HER+.  HER+ tumors are frequently resistant to tamoxifen.
Posts.Title: clarification

Posts.Content: just a question. You posted under the lymphoma site, but a "lumpectomy" does imply breast cancer.
Posts.Title: New-just Had Lumpectomy-lymph Node Question

Posts.Content: you didnt mention your age but in younger women lumps are more likely to be non cancerous.  If you are under 40, less than 10% of lumps turn out to be cancer.  Does it change in size or come and go during your cycle?  In post menopausal women, lumps are a greater concern.  In general a cyst is fluid filled so it feels like a water ballon.  A  tumor is hard.  As others have said you need to get it checked, with or without insurance.
Posts.Title: cist or cancer

Posts.Content: er/pr status?  Multifocal ?  Your age?    Usually lumpectomy plus radiation is fine for DCIS.  If you opt for mastectomy you could avoid the radiation.  You could do the lumpectomy, see how the margins were and then do mastectomy if needed.
Posts.Title: DCIS O stage

Posts.Content: On 5/11/2007 Angelocks wrote: I just received the news that my 49 year old sister has HER2-NU Cancer stage 3 of the right breast. She recently had a mastectomy done of her right breast and three lymph nodes removed. No cancer was found on her nodes, however, the doctor says this is aggressive cancer and the prognosis is grim. Needless to say, we are all devasted. I need some feedback from your personal experiences; what my sister can expect, available treatments, nutrion, exercise, and of course prognosis. I hear Herceptin is the drug used to treat this cancer, is this drug FDA approved? We live close to the Mexican border, and I wonder if it can be purchased there without a prescription. I am encouraging my sister to seek a second opinion and not to give up. Together we can beat this horrible decease. I also heard that this type of breat cancer is genetically link. We are six sisters and 12 nieces between us all. What should we look for or avoid? Any advise would be helpful. Thanks! Angelocksstage 3 does imply LN involvement unless its a IIIB, which means the tumor is bigger.  It is true that generally the HER tumors are more agressive and resistant to treatment.  The good news is that Herceptin can be used in HER tumors.  It is FDA approved.  I am not sure about its status in Mexico.   She should probably also get some of her pre surgery chemo, especially if it appeared effective.  Do you know the ER status?  Most breat cancer is NOT inherited and I am not aware that HER + has any genetic link.  Dont worry too much about prognosis.  Others have survived this.
Posts.Title: HER2-NU

Posts.Content: most lumps are not cancer. However ,you should get it checked out by a doctor. A mammogram may not be necessary at all. You mentioned you dont want to see a doc, but thats the place to start. Why no health insurance? Are you self employed? Good luck and dont give up !
Posts.Title: Can't Seem to Get Help Getting a Mammogram

Posts.Content: There are two masses. The one in your breast is a "suspicious growth". The one under your arm is your lymph node which that breast drains into. The biopsy can involve the breast mass or the lymph node or both. Often when the lymph node is biopsied, the entire node is removed.
Posts.Title: Having Biopsy Confused...

Posts.Content: Faslodex is an estrogen receptor blocker, not actually chemo so no hair loss.  Its side effects could be similiar to the Femara.  Weakness, tiredness and pain seem to be common.  At least the shot is only once a month.
Posts.Title: Estrogen therapy

Posts.Content: The PET is used to detect rapid cell metabolism which could indicate metastatic disease.   Your mom has a LN with uptake, but has not changed in size.  The lesions in the vertebral bodies have no uptake and have not changed.  This indicates no change since the last PET which is good.
Posts.Title: FDG Uptake Explanation - PET SCAN

Posts.Content: uptake is the amount of radioactive sugar that the cells are using for metabolism.   It is possible to have a positive area on PET that is not cancer.  Thats why its important to compare one scan to the next to see if there are changes.  This could be an increase in the number of areas that light up or an increase in activity in the same area.  Since your moms have not changed, this would be a good sign.  I would also ask your oncologist or radiologist for their explaination.
Posts.Title: FDG Uptake Explanation - PET SCAN

Posts.Content: the SUV is pretty low (6.7), but the concern is that there wasnt any activity on the last PET and now there is.  The only way to be sure is to biopsy the LN.  Is she planning to repeat the PET in one month?
Posts.Title: FDG Uptake Explanation - PET SCAN

Posts.Content: The problems I am aware of involve Paxil or other SSRI's and tamoxifen.  The problem appears to be that Paxil and SSRI's can prevent the liver from converting tamoxifen into its active form. If you were on tamoxifen then switching your antidepressant to Effexor appears to help and avoids the interaction.  I am not aware of any problem with Aromosin and Paxil.
Posts.Title: Increased breast cancer risk taking Paxil?

Posts.Content: I would ask your oncologist what the plan is for following the hot LN.  A physical exam does not sound like a biopsy or a PET.
Posts.Title: FDG Uptake Explanation - PET SCAN

Posts.Content: spiculated masses are suggestive of but not diagnostic of cancer.  The biopsy will tell that.  More than 50% of these are cancer.  Let us know what you find out.
Posts.Title: 12mm spiculated mass

Posts.Content: I went back and read your original post and had a question.  In the last PET (last year) was there uptake in that level II LN?  This report says the size and morphology are the same and uptake this time but I cant tell if there was uptake in that LN last time.  If there was no uptake last time, but now there is,  then that could be a sign of metastatic activity.  See what your oncologist/radiologist thinks.
Posts.Title: FDG Uptake Explanation - PET SCAN

Posts.Content: I would ask your oncologist what the plan is for following the hot LN.  A physical exam does not sound like a biopsy or a PET.
Posts.Title: FDG Uptake Explanation - PET SCAN

Posts.Content: there are 3 grades of DCIS.   Grade 3 is the most likely to become invasive.  You should learn more from the biopsy.
Posts.Title: new diagnosis--please help!

Posts.Content: I would call Saw Palmetto a mild estrogen blocker.  Check with your doc before starting any OTC products.
Posts.Title: Caffeine and breast cancer

Posts.Content: Just to be clear, this drug is NOT being pulled from the market.  Avastin got FDA approval for breast cancer in 2008.  In the followup studies that were a condition of approval the same benefit was not demonstrated.  As a result the FDA is considering removing the indication for breast cancer.  Even if the FDA withdraws the drug's approval for breast cancer, doctors will still have the option to prescribe the drug "off-label."
Posts.Title: AVASTIN is being pulled from the market!!!!

Posts.Content: It is basically true that insurance companies may stop paying for any drug that does not have an FDA indication.  However that may vary some from company to company.  It also may take companies some time to catch up with the FDA decision.  In addition, you and your physician could make an appeal to your insurance company for coverage based on current literature.  At $6-7 K per dose, paying out of your own pocket would be expensive.
Posts.Title: AVASTIN is being pulled from the market!!!!

Posts.Content: Check this web site: http://www.hifu.ca/home/index.php I believe they are in Toronto.
Posts.Title: High Intensity Focused Ultrasound(hifu)

Posts.Content: you are wise to have such a positive attitude. Are you saying you cant come back because of your treatments? What about part time? Remember this: Look at the birds of the air; they do not sow or reap or store away in barns, and yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are you not much more valuable than they?
Posts.Title: my Postion is Being Filled Once my Fmla is Exhausted

Posts.Content: I know HIFU is being studied in brest cancer although Im not sure about its use in metastatic disease. It is only availble in the US in clinical trials, I believe. I have heard the cost in Canada is $15,000- $20,000.
Posts.Title: High Intensity Focused Ultrasound(hifu)

Posts.Content: Her2 is a protein on the surface of cells which is a key compoment in regulating cell growth. When the her2 protein is altered, extra receptors are produced. This over-expression causes increased growth and reproduction of cells. 20-30% of breast cancers are her2 +. Herceptin is a drug which blocks these recetors and slows the growth and spread of tumors. If you are her2 +, you should probably be on Herceptin.
Posts.Title: Her2-neu Positive/node Negative
